dict.string: Complete mission 1 with a score of 3 stars
Complete mission 1 having at least 10 evolution points at the end

The first human ancestors appeared 4 million yeas ago in the forests of East Africa.
The oldest species were called Australopithecines. They already walked in two legs, and it seems that this property allowed them very important for their success. They managed to live in a diversity of environments, from forests to savannah.
First draft of Murphy's Toast logo! It was drawn in a bar...
Complete mission 2 with a score of 3 stars

Australopithecus, Homo Habilis or Homo Neanderthal were different species of hominins. They were quite diverse, but all of them shared being bipeds, having small teeth and big brains. Homo Sapiens is the only surviving hominin.

"Science is the belief in the ignorance of experts."
Richard Feynman (one of the most important physicists of XXth century)
Complete mission 3 with a score of 3 stars

The british ship HMS Beagle left Plymouth in 1831 towards South America. A young man called Charled Darwin was onboard, and the data he collected during the voyage was crucial to develop his theory of evolution by natural selection. They returned to Europe 5 years later after circumnavigating the Earth. ACH_LVL3_3 Culture makes humans so flexible that they currently live in all environments that can be imagined.
The Tubu live in an African region called Ténéré, the country of emptiness. The women are able to find the only water well in thousands of squared kilometers with the only orientation of dune movement and the stars.
TITLE_LVL4_COMPLETED INTRODUCING TECH DESCR_LVL4_COMPLETED Complete mission 4 TITLE_LVL4_PERFECT PERFECTION 4 DESCR_LVL4_PERFECT Complete mission 4 with a score of 3 stars
ACH_LVL4_2 Our ancestors started using tools 2 million ago. Technology was not an isolated innovation, as it seems that hominins also started using language during the same period.
ACH_LVL4_3 Culture is not only a human thing. Apes, dolphins and orcas also have complex cultural traits such as tools and language. However, the pace at which we learn and create new ideas makes us quite different than the rest of the animals.
TITLE_LVL5_COMPLETED GETTING AWAY DESCR_LVL5_COMPLETED Complete mission 5 TITLE_LVL5_PERFECT PERFECTION 5 DESCR_LVL5_PERFECT Complete mission 5 with a score of 3 stars
TITLE_LVL6_COMPLETED INFLUENCER DESCR_LVL6_COMPLETED Complete mission 6 TITLE_LVL6_PERFECT PERFECTION 6 DESCR_LVL6_PERFECT Complete mission 6 with a score of 3 stars
ACH_LVL6_2 Breakthroughs in biology has proved that part of our genetic information comes form Neanderthals.
Considering that they are not our ancestors, this hybridation means that both species coexisted and interbred in Europe.
TITLE_LVL7_COMPLETED CALL TO ARMS DESCR_LVL7_COMPLETED Complete mission 7 TITLE_LVL7_PERFECT PERFECTION 7 DESCR_LVL7_PERFECT Complete mission 7 with a score of 3 stars
TITLE_LVL8_COMPLETED THE CROSSING DESCR_LVL8_COMPLETED Complete mission 8 TITLE_LVL8_PERFECT PERFECTION 8 DESCR_LVL8_PERFECT Complete mission 8 with a score of 3 stars
ACH_LVL8_2 Did you know that what is considered the first feature-length documentary in film history is about hunter-gatherer people? Nanook of the North (also known as Nanook of the North: A Story of Life and Love in the Actual Arctic) is a 1922 silent documentary film by Robert J. Flaherty, which describes the life and the fight for survival of Nanook and his family, members of the Inuit people of the Canadian Arctic.
TITLE_LVL9_COMPLETED JOINING FORCES DESCR_LVL9_COMPLETED Complete mission 9 TITLE_LVL9_PERFECT PERFECTION 9 DESCR_LVL9_PERFECT Complete mission 9 with a score of 3 stars
ACH_LVL9_2 We don't know why Neanderthals became extinct: conflict with Sapiens? Climate change? Competition for resources? All of them?
Understanding the extinction of Neanderthals is extremely interesting because it can help us understand the dangers we currently face.
ACH_LEVEL9_3 The more we know about Neanderthals the more we see how similar we are. This fascination has generated interesting fiction works, such as the novels "The Clan of the Cave Bear" by J.M. Auel and the science-fiction trilogy "The Neanderthal Parallax", by Robert J. Sawyer.
